TopicTitle: [RemoteTech / HyperEdit] Cannot keep satellites in an orbit that matches the Mun

Articles.Content:
I've been struggling with my Mun comms network.

I have two sattelites in an orbit that matches the Mun's but are outside it's SOI. I launched them and got them as accurate as possible then, in order to avoid constant station keeping, HyperEdited them to perfectly match the Mun's orbit.

 

However, over time, they eventually end up in the Mun's SOI and I have to keep using HE to keep them in place. I deliberately avoid loading them to keep the orbits as HE sets them, so I'm not sure what's happening.

The orbits are as follows:

Any suggestions as to why these satellites end up in Mun's SOI eventually?

 

One thing I noticed this time is that HE doesn't seem to be ablt to set some values to exactly zero. When I double check, I find that Inc and Long.A.Node are set to 0.0001, not zero. Might it be this?

 

Has anyone managed to set orbits to match the Mun's and keep them there long-term? Or any suggestions as to how I might achieve this?

small inaccuracies should not matter with LAN and inclination. 

In HyperEdit, can you actually type in semimajor axis or is it altitude above sea level? Because altitude would not include Kerbin's radius (which is 600km).

On 13.8.2016 at 8:22 PM, Cooper42 said:

One thing I noticed this time is that HE doesn't seem to be ablt to set some values to exactly zero. When I double check, I find that Inc and Long.A.Node are set to 0.0001, not zero. Might it be this?

That's a result of the way a computer stores floating point numbers (AKA numbers that are not whole, which would be called integers). Floating point numbers are always only precise to a certain degree. Even if you try to store an integer like 0 as a floating point, the mere act of conversion introduces an imprecision.

It's entirely possible that floating point errors of some description cause the orbits to be ever so slightly out of sync with the Mun. Have you tried leaving more margin for error? As in, putting the satellites further ahead of and further behind the Mun's SOI, so that there needs to be a whole lot more drift before an encounter happens? Even IRL, riding the razor edge of something is often a recipe for trouble
